observations.statement: User experience is shaped by both administrative and regular user perspectives.
observations.quote: I had administrative credentials, if you will, privileges... that, frankly, colored my impression and my utilization of the website.

observations.statement: Users find the Wild Apricot application flexible and powerful for nonprofit needs.
observations.quote: I was impressed with wild apricot application in terms of what they were doing for nonprofit organizations like the newcomers.

observations.statement: The phone app is seen as underpowered and conflicting, causing frustration for users.
observations.quote: I rarely use the phone app, quite frankly, because I felt it was underpowered and gave conflicting information.

observations.statement: Clear communication about registration status is a significant issue.
observations.quote: I'm looking at the actual log here. And your registration expired because you didn't pay within the first 15 minutes.

observations.statement: Regular users rely heavily on the website for event information.
observations.quote: I found the news a hugely important source of information.

observations.statement: Users appreciate the ability to see who is attending events as a social connector.
observations.quote: I like the feature of being able to see who's actually already registered for events.

observations.statement: Event descriptions can lack clarity and transparency, leading to confusion.
observations.quote: Sometimes the event descriptions... were not as transparent or not as clear as they could be.

observations.statement: Users prioritize functionality over aesthetics when navigating websites.
observations.quote: I'm looking for utility... I want to do my business and I want to get out.

observations.statement: There is a lack of institutional memory due to frequent turnover in leadership.
observations.quote: The problem is the lack of a formalized institutional memory.

observations.statement: Training for new committee members is inadequate and needs improvement.
observations.quote: The training process really needs to have some hard, hard look at two issues.

observations.statement: The VP of activities should have prior experience with the system for effectiveness.
observations.quote: The requirement for the VP of activities absolutely has to be someone who has been a not only a co-chair.

observations.statement: Event management requires familiarity with the system, which new users lack.
observations.quote: The brand new person that's just getting going is really challenged by that.

observations.statement: Printed name tags are important for large events to verify registrations.
observations.quote: If I saw anyone walking around with a name tag... that was a clue that that person may not have been registered.

observations.statement: There is a need for a technical resource person to assist with event organization.
observations.quote: There ought to be a paid technical kind of person that really could be there, you know, as the glue to hold together all the aspects.

observations.statement: Users desire a more streamlined process for creating and managing events.
observations.quote: The mechanics of what I'm going to refer to as the back office work.

observations.statement: User feedback indicates that the website requires ongoing updates and improvements.
observations.quote: There are a couple of bumps in the road, of course, with everything.

observations.statement: Users are willing to pay for added value in services, such as alumni relations.
observations.quote: I'd be willing to pay 25 bucks a year for that privilege.

observations.statement: Users value the social aspect of events and networking opportunities.
observations.quote: I want to contact your friends and so forth and so on.

observations.statement: Event planning requires attention to detail, especially with cancellations and waitlists.
observations.quote: How do you manage a wait list? All of that is important.

observations.statement: Users experience a steep learning curve when transitioning into new roles.
observations.quote: The learning curve just hits the peak at the time of transition.

observations.statement: Frequent changes in leadership can hinder continuity and effective event planning.
observations.quote: Imagine running an organization, a corporation like that.

observations.statement: Users want a cleaner and simpler interface for better usability.
observations.quote: Cleaner, simpler, better is my approach.

observations.statement: Regular users often feel overwhelmed by the technical aspects of event management.
observations.quote: The mechanics of what I'm going to refer to as the back office work.

observations.statement: Users appreciate features that enhance the event experience, such as name tags.
observations.quote: I like the printed name tags as an audit function.

observations.statement: Users feel positive about the overall functionality of the website despite its flaws.
observations.quote: It's astounding to me that this thing works as well as it does.

statements.POVStatement: Newcomers need an improved mobile app experience because they often find it confusing and unreliable, leading to frustration when trying to register for events.
statements.SupportingEvidence: the phone app says you registered. But you know what? I'm looking at the actual log here. And your registration expired because you didn't pay within the first 15 minutes.
statements.UnderlyingUserNeed: A seamless and reliable mobile experience for event registration.
statements.KeyInsight: Users primarily rely on their phones, and inconsistencies create barriers to participation.

statements.POVStatement: Committee chairs need better training on the event management system because they struggle with the complexity of the process, hindering their ability to execute successful events.
statements.SupportingEvidence: the training process that is undertaken in good faith is really not adequate to allow a committee co-chair to be facile in terms of how to understand and how to use to its greatest potential.
statements.UnderlyingUserNeed: Effective training resources for new users of the event management system.
statements.KeyInsight: Without proper training, new committee members feel overwhelmed and underprepared, affecting event quality.

statements.POVStatement: Newcomers need clearer event descriptions and scheduling information because they often encounter confusion over conflicting details, impacting their ability to plan effectively.
statements.SupportingEvidence: sometimes the event descriptions and especially save the date kinds of things or conflicting scheduling things were not as transparent or not as clear as they could be.
statements.UnderlyingUserNeed: Accurate and accessible information about events.
statements.KeyInsight: Clarity in communication is essential for engagement and attendance at events.

statements.POVStatement: Newcomers need a way to document and share institutional knowledge because the frequent turnover of committee members creates a lack of continuity and memory for best practices.
statements.SupportingEvidence: the lack of a formalized institutional memory...to be able to pass that baton to the next term.
statements.UnderlyingUserNeed: A reliable system for capturing and sharing historical knowledge.
statements.KeyInsight: Continuity in processes is vital for organizational success and member satisfaction.

statements.POVStatement: Event organizers need a streamlined system for generating printed name tags because it helps in identifying attendees and managing registrations effectively.
statements.SupportingEvidence: I like the printed name tags as an audit function...to quickly spot...anyone walking around with a name tag that was a pencil, sharpie, handwritten name tag rather than a printed name tag.
statements.UnderlyingUserNeed: An efficient method for managing event registrations and participant identification.
statements.KeyInsight: Clear identification enhances networking and ensures proper registration management.

statements.POVStatement: Newcomers need a dedicated technical support person because the administrative tasks can overwhelm volunteers, preventing them from focusing on event planning.
statements.SupportingEvidence: having that kind of capacity would be significant...the mechanics of what I'm going to refer to as the back office work.
statements.UnderlyingUserNeed: Technical assistance to alleviate administrative burdens.
statements.KeyInsight: Reducing administrative strain allows volunteers to apply their efforts toward creative event planning.

statements.POVStatement: Newcomers need user-friendly access to event registration data because it allows them to manage their events more effectively and ensure participant satisfaction.
statements.SupportingEvidence: the notion of doing printed name tags...is an issue when you've got over 100 people.
statements.UnderlyingUserNeed: Easy access to registration and participant data.
statements.KeyInsight: Effective data management is critical for large event coordination and attendee experience.

statements.POVStatement: Newcomers need a more vibrant and engaging online presence because a refreshed website can attract more participation from users who are seeking social connections.
statements.SupportingEvidence: the good news and the bad news about newcomers is it reinvents itself every six months.
statements.UnderlyingUserNeed: A dynamic and appealing platform for community engagement.
statements.KeyInsight: A vibrant online presence fosters community involvement and participation.

questions.HMW_question: How might we enhance the usability of the phone app for newcomers?
questions.problem/need: Users struggle with the phone app's functionality, leading to confusion.
questions.supporting_evidence: I had more problems with the phone app than I did with the computer based web application.

questions.HMW_question: How might we improve the onboarding process for new committee members?
questions.problem/need: New members find it challenging to understand the event organization process.
questions.supporting_evidence: The training process that is undertaken in good faith is really not adequate to allow a committee co-chair to be facile.

questions.HMW_question: How might we create a centralized knowledge repository for event management best practices?
questions.problem/need: Lack of institutional memory leads to repeated mistakes in event organization.
questions.supporting_evidence: There’s not a facile way to have some kind of archival process or some way to, you know, to put in a note to the file for the information.

questions.HMW_question: How might we streamline the event registration process to reduce confusion?
questions.problem/need: Users are confused about their registration status due to conflicting information.
questions.supporting_evidence: I'm looking at the actual log here. And your registration expired because you didn't pay within the first 15 minutes.

questions.HMW_question: How might we ensure clear communication about event details to users?
questions.problem/need: Users find event descriptions and schedules unclear.
questions.supporting_evidence: Event descriptions and especially save the date kinds of things or conflicting scheduling things were not as transparent or not as clear.

questions.HMW_question: How might we leverage technology to automate event management tasks?
questions.problem/need: Manual processes bog down event organization.
questions.supporting_evidence: The mechanics of what I'm going to refer to as the back office work.

questions.HMW_question: How might we provide better training resources for event coordinators?
questions.problem/need: Current training resources are inadequate for new event coordinators.
questions.supporting_evidence: The training process really needs to have some hard, hard look at two issues.

questions.HMW_question: How might we integrate alumni into the newcomers community effectively?
questions.problem/need: Alumni are not currently engaged in a meaningful way.
questions.supporting_evidence: How we can fold alumni into that in a comfortable kind of way.

questions.HMW_question: How might we develop a more user-friendly interface for the newcomers website?
questions.problem/need: The website's current interface may not be inviting for new users.
questions.supporting_evidence: Cleaner, simpler, better is my approach.

questions.HMW_question: How might we implement a system for printed name tags that serves both aesthetic and functional purposes?
questions.problem/need: Handwritten name tags can create confusion about registration status.
questions.supporting_evidence: If I saw anyone walking around with a name tag that was a pencil, sharpie, handwritten name tag... that was a clue that that person may not have been registered.

questions.HMW_question: How might we create a more reliable way to track event registrations?
questions.problem/need: Inaccurate registration tracking leads to participant confusion.
questions.supporting_evidence: My phone app says I'm registered. I'm sorry. So anyway, the point is a major area of improvement would be to improve the interface.

questions.HMW_question: How might we foster a culture of knowledge sharing within the newcomers organization?
questions.problem/need: There is a lack of shared knowledge among committee members.
questions.supporting_evidence: The only behind the scenes person that really has any long term history is Charlie.

questions.HMW_question: How might we improve the clarity of event scheduling information on the website?
questions.problem/need: Users struggle to find clear and concise scheduling information.
questions.supporting_evidence: Conflicting scheduling things were not as transparent or not as clear.

questions.HMW_question: How might we create a feedback mechanism for users to report issues with the website/app?
questions.problem/need: Users have trouble communicating their issues with the platform.
questions.supporting_evidence: The biggest problem I had with the whole process, frankly, was dealing with people who were not savvy users.

insights.insight_statement: Users with administrative privileges have a different experience than regular users, leading to insights about potential usability issues.
insights.supporting_evidence: David mentioned, 'I had more problems with the phone app than I did with the computer based web application.'
insights.why_it_matters: Understanding the disparity in experiences can inform design decisions to cater to both administrative and regular users, ensuring that functionalities meet the needs of all user types.

insights.insight_statement: The mobile app is perceived as underpowered and creates confusion among users.
insights.supporting_evidence: '...I felt it was underpowered and gave conflicting information.'
insights.why_it_matters: Improving the mobile app's functionality could enhance user satisfaction and reduce frustration, particularly among users who primarily rely on mobile devices.

insights.insight_statement: Users value clarity and transparency in event information but find descriptions often lacking.
insights.supporting_evidence: '...event descriptions and especially save the date kinds of things or conflicting scheduling things were not as transparent or not as clear...'
insights.why_it_matters: Enhancing the clarity of event information could improve user engagement and event participation, as users are more likely to attend events they clearly understand.

insights.insight_statement: There is a significant knowledge gap in the training and onboarding process for new committee members.
insights.supporting_evidence: '...the training process really needs to have some hard, hard look at two issues... the venue for training has been woefully inadequate.'
insights.why_it_matters: Addressing this gap can enable new members to effectively use the system, thereby improving overall event management and user experience.

insights.insight_statement: Institutional memory is lacking, leading to repeated learning curves for new members.
insights.supporting_evidence: '...the lack of a formalized institutional memory... there’s not a facile way to have some kind of archival process...'
insights.why_it_matters: Creating a system for preserving institutional knowledge can smooth transitions and maintain continuity, benefiting both new and returning members.

insights.insight_statement: Printed name tags serve a dual purpose of identification and as an audit function for event registration.
insights.supporting_evidence: '...if I saw anyone walking around with a name tag that was a pencil, sharpie, handwritten name tag rather than a printed name tag... that was a clue that that person may not have been registered...'
insights.why_it_matters: Incorporating printed name tags can enhance event organization and registration verification, contributing to a smoother attendee experience.

insights.insight_statement: Users prioritize utility over aesthetics in website design.
insights.supporting_evidence: '...I want to do my business and I want to get out. And so from that perspective, cleaner, simpler, better is my approach.'
insights.why_it_matters: Focusing on utility in design can lead to increased user satisfaction and more efficient interactions with the website.

insights.insight_statement: There is a demand for a dedicated technical support role to assist with event management.
insights.supporting_evidence: '...there ought to be a paid technical kind of person that really could be there, you know, as the glue to hold together...'
insights.why_it_matters: Implementing a dedicated support role could relieve administrative burdens from committee members and improve event execution.

insights.insight_statement: The organization experiences high turnover, affecting continuity and event planning.
insights.supporting_evidence: '...it reinvents itself every six months... the learning curve just hits the peak at the time of transition.'
insights.why_it_matters: A strategy to address turnover, such as extending terms or improving training, could enhance the stability and effectiveness of event planning.

stages.name: Discovery
actions: Exploring the website for event information
thoughts: Is there an event I want to attend?
What are my friends doing this week?
painPoints: Lack of clarity in event descriptions
opportunities: Enhance the newsletter format for better readability

stages.name: Planning
thoughts: How do I ensure everyone's registered?
Is the app providing accurate information?
painPoints: Inconsistencies between app and website data
Difficulty in managing registrations and waitlists
opportunities: Improve app functionality for ease of use

stages.name: Execution
thoughts: How can we improve the event experience?
opportunities: Implement a system for printed name tags for easy identification
Create a better follow-up process for cancellations

stages.name: Reflection
painPoints: Lack of formalized processes for feedback
Difficulty in remembering past experiences due to turnover
opportunities: Create an archive of past events and learnings
